tests.name: join-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: join with default separator
puts [join {a b c}]

tests.name: join-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: join with custom separator
puts [join {a b c} -]
puts [join {a b c} ", "]

tests.name: join-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: join with empty separator
puts [join {a b c} ""]

tests.name: join-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: join empty list returns empty string
puts "[join {}]."

tests.name: join-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: join single element
puts [join {hello}]

tests.name: join-1.5
join-1.6
join-1.7
tests.script:
# Test: join with newline separator
puts [join {a b c} "\n"]

tests.name: join-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: join with braced elements - removes one level of bracing
puts [join {{a b} {c d}}]

tests.name: join-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: join nested lists - only flattens one level
puts [join {a {b {c d}} e}]

tests.name: join-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: join with tab separator
puts [join {a b c} "\t"]

tests.name: join-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: join with special characters in separator
puts [join {1 2 3} " + "]

tests.name: join-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: join single element list with custom separator
puts [join {only} "::"]

tests.name: join-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: join with empty elements in list
puts "[join {{} a {} b {}}]."

tests.name: join-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: join with separator containing special chars
puts [join {a b c} {$}]

tests.name: join-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: join result is not a list (spaces become part of string)
set result [join {"a b" "c d"} :]
puts $result

tests.name: lappend-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: lappend to empty variable
lappend x a b c
puts $x

tests.name: lappend-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: lappend to existing list
set x {a b}
lappend x c d
puts $x

tests.name: lappend-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: lappend builds up a list incrementally
set var 1
lappend var 2
puts $var
lappend var 3 4 5
puts $var

tests.name: lappend-1.3
lappend-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: lappend properly quotes elements with spaces
set x {a b}
lappend x "c d"
puts $x

tests.name: lappend-1.5
lappend-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: lappend with empty string element
set x {a b}
lappend x ""
puts $x
puts [llength $x]

tests.name: lappend-2.1
lappend-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: lappend to non-existent variable with no values
lappend newvar
puts "[llength $newvar]."

tests.name: lappend-3.0
lappend-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: lappend multiple values at once to new variable
lappend brand_new a b c d e
puts $brand_new
puts [llength $brand_new]

tests.name: lappend-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: lappend with braces in element
set x {a}
lappend x "b{c}d"
puts $x

tests.name: lappend-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: chained lappend calls
set x {}
lappend x a
lappend x b
lappend x c
puts $x

tests.name: lindex-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: lindex basic indexing
puts [lindex {a b c} 0]
puts [lindex {a b c} 1]
puts [lindex {a b c} 2]

tests.name: lindex-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with end index
puts [lindex {a b c} end]
puts [lindex {a b c} end-1]

tests.name: lindex-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with no index returns the list
puts [lindex {a b c}]
puts [lindex {a b c} {}]
tests.stdout:
a b c
a b c

tests.name: lindex-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: lindex out of bounds returns empty
puts "[lindex {a b c} 5]."
puts "[lindex {a b c} -1]."

tests.name: lindex-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: lindex nested list with multiple indices
puts [lindex {{a b c} {d e f} {g h i}} 2 1]

tests.name: lindex-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: lindex deeply nested
puts [lindex {{{a b} {c d}} {{e f} {g h}}} 1 1 0]

tests.name: lindex-1.6
tests.script:
# Test: lindex end-2
puts [lindex {a b c d e} end-2]

tests.name: lindex-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with indices as list argument
puts [lindex {{a b c} {d e f} {g h i}} {2 1}]

tests.name: lindex-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with deeply nested indices as list
puts [lindex {{{a b} {c d}} {{e f} {g h}}} {1 1 0}]

tests.name: lindex-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: lindex on empty list
puts "[lindex {} 0]."

tests.name: lindex-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: lindex extracts braced element correctly
puts [lindex {{hello world} foo} 0]

tests.name: lindex-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with end-N where N equals list length (returns empty)
puts "[lindex {a b c} end-3]."

tests.name: lindex-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with index having leading zeros
puts [lindex {a b c d e} 02]

tests.name: lindex-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: lindex multiple separate index arguments
puts [lindex {{{a b} {c d}} {{e f} {g h}}} 0 1 1]

tests.name: lindex-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: lindex with single element list
puts [lindex {only} 0]
puts [lindex {only} end]

tests.name: lindex-3.4
tests.script:
# Test: lindex on list with empty elements
puts "[lindex {{} a {} b {}} 0]."
puts [lindex {{} a {} b {}} 1]
puts "[lindex {{} a {} b {}} 2]."

tests.name: list-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: list with no arguments returns empty list
puts [list]

tests.name: list-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: list with single argument
puts [list a]

tests.name: list-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: list with multiple arguments
puts [list a b c]

tests.name: list-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: list properly quotes elements with spaces
puts [list a "b c" d]

tests.name: list-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: list with element containing braces
puts [list a {b c} d]

tests.name: list-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: list example from manual page
puts [list a b "c d e  " "  f {g h}"]
tests.stdout: a b {c d e  } {  f {g h}}

tests.name: list-1.6
tests.script:
# Test: list preserves empty elements
puts [list "" a "" b ""]

tests.name: list-1.7
tests.script:
# Test: list with newlines and tabs
puts [list "a\nb" "c\td"]

tests.name: list-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: list roundtrip - lindex can extract original elements
set mylist [list a "b c" {d e}]
puts [lindex $mylist 0]
puts [lindex $mylist 1]
puts [lindex $mylist 2]

tests.name: list-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: list with backslash characters
puts [list "a\\b" "c\td"]

tests.name: list-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: list with special list characters - brackets
puts [list "\[a\]" "\{b\}"]

tests.name: list-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: list with dollar sign (braced, no substitution)
puts [list {$var} {$x}]

tests.name: list-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: list with semicolons (command separator)
puts [list "a;b" "c;d;e"]

tests.name: list-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: list with embedded quotes
puts [list {a"b} {c"d"e}]

tests.name: list-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: list with trailing backslash
puts [list "a\\" "b\\\\"]

tests.name: list-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: list with whitespace-only elements
puts [list " " "  " "\t"]

tests.name: list-3.4
tests.script:
# Test: list with hash character (comment in TCL)
puts [list "#comment" "a#b"]

tests.name: list-3.5
tests.script:
# Test: nested list creation
set inner [list a b c]
set outer [list $inner x y]
puts $outer

tests.name: llength-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: llength of empty list
puts [llength {}]

tests.name: llength-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: llength of list with elements
puts [llength {a b c}]

tests.name: llength-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: llength with braced elements
puts [llength {a b {c d} e}]

tests.name: llength-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: llength with empty braced element
puts [llength {a b { } c d e}]

tests.name: llength-1.4
llength-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: llength single element
puts [llength {hello}]
puts [llength hello]

tests.name: llength-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: llength with deeply nested list
puts [llength {a {b {c {d}}}}]

tests.name: llength-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: llength with quoted strings
puts [llength {"hello world" "foo bar"}]

tests.name: llength-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: llength with multiple consecutive spaces in list (treated as one separator)
puts [llength {a    b    c}]

tests.name: llength-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: llength with newlines as separators
puts [llength {a
b
c}]

tests.name: llength-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: llength with tabs as separators
puts [llength "a\tb\tc"]

tests.name: llength-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: llength with mixed leading/trailing whitespace
puts [llength "  a b c  "]

tests.name: llength-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: llength with element containing backslash
puts [llength {a\ b c}]

tests.name: lrange-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: lrange basic
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 1 3]

tests.name: lrange-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with end
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 2 end]
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 0 end-1]
tests.stdout:
c d e
a b c d

tests.name: lrange-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: lrange first two elements
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 0 1]

tests.name: lrange-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: lrange last three elements
puts [lrange {a b c d e} end-2 end]

tests.name: lrange-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: lrange everything except first and last
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 1 end-1]

tests.name: lrange-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: lrange first > last returns empty
puts "[lrange {a b c} 2 0]."

tests.name: lrange-1.6
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with negative first (treated as 0)
puts [lrange {a b c d e} -5 2]

tests.name: lrange-1.7
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with last past end (treated as end)
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 2 100]

tests.name: lrange-1.8
tests.script:
# Test: lrange vs lindex for braced elements
set var {some {elements to} select}
puts [lindex $var 1]
puts [lrange $var 1 1]

tests.name: lrange-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: lrange on empty list
puts "[lrange {} 0 1]."

tests.name: lrange-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: lrange full list extraction
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 0 end]

tests.name: lrange-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: lrange single element list
puts [lrange {only} 0 0]

tests.name: lrange-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: lrange preserves bracing
puts [lrange {{a b} {c d} {e f}} 0 1]

tests.name: lrange-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with end-N where N is large (first becomes negative)
puts "[lrange {a b c} end-10 end-10]."

tests.name: lrange-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with first=end, last=end
puts [lrange {a b c d e} end end]

tests.name: lrange-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: lrange preserves empty elements
puts [lrange {{} a {} b {}} 0 2]

tests.name: lrange-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: lrange with mixed end and number indices
puts [lrange {a b c d e} 1 end-2]

tests.name: lsort-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: lsort alphabetically
puts [lsort {banana apple cherry}]

tests.name: lsort-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: lsort decreasing
puts [lsort -decreasing {a b c}]

tests.name: lsort-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: lsort integer
puts [lsort -integer {10 2 5 1}]

tests.name: lsort-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: lsort ASCII sorting (default)
puts [lsort {a10 B2 b1 a1 a2}]

tests.name: lsort-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: lsort integer with various formats
puts [lsort -integer {5 3 1 2 11 4}]

tests.name: lsort-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: lsort decreasing integer
puts [lsort -decreasing -integer {5 3 1 2 11 4}]

tests.name: lsort-1.6
tests.script:
# Test: lsort empty list
puts "[lsort {}]."

tests.name: lsort-1.7
tests.script:
# Test: lsort single element
puts [lsort {hello}]

tests.name: lsort-1.8
tests.script:
# Test: lsort with -increasing (explicit, same as default)
puts [lsort -increasing {c b a}]

tests.name: lsort-1.9
tests.script:
# Test: lsort with negative integers
puts [lsort -integer {-5 3 -1 0 2}]

tests.name: lsort-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: lsort with duplicate elements
puts [lsort {c a b a c b}]
tests.stdout: a a b b c c

tests.name: lsort-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: lsort preserves list element structure
puts [lsort {{z first} {a second} {m third}}]

tests.name: lsort-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: lsort integer decreasing combined
puts [lsort -integer -decreasing {1 10 2 20 3}]

tests.name: lsort-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: lsort ascii is case-sensitive (uppercase before lowercase)
puts [lsort {a B c A b C}]
tests.stdout: A B C a b c

tests.name: lsort-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -nocase
puts [lsort -nocase {Banana apple Cherry}]

tests.name: lsort-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -unique removes duplicates
puts [lsort -unique {c a b a c b a}]

tests.name: lsort-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -real for floating point numbers
puts [lsort -real {3.14 2.71 1.41 1.73}]

tests.name: lsort-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -dictionary
puts [lsort -dictionary {a10 a2 a1 a20}]

tests.name: lsort-3.4
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -unique -integer combined
puts [lsort -unique -integer {3 1 2 1 3 2}]

tests.name: lsort-3.5
tests.script:
# Test: lsort -nocase -decreasing combined
puts [lsort -nocase -decreasing {a B c A b C}]
tests.stdout: c C B b a A

tests.name: split-1.0
tests.script:
# Test: split with default separator
puts [split "a b c"]

tests.name: split-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: split with custom separator
puts [split "a-b-c" -]
puts [split "a,b,c" ,]
tests.stdout:
a b c
a b c

tests.name: split-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: split into characters
puts [split "abc" ""]

tests.name: split-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: split on dot for path-like strings
puts [split "comp.lang.tcl" .]

tests.name: split-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: split with adjacent separators creates empty elements
puts [split "a::b" :]

tests.name: split-1.5
tests.script:
# Test: split with separator at start and end
puts [split ":a:b:" :]

tests.name: split-1.6
tests.script:
# Test: split into characters (Hello world example from manual)
puts [split "Hello world" {}]
tests.stdout: H e l l o { } w o r l d

tests.name: split-1.7
tests.script:
# Test: split empty string
puts [llength [split "" :]]

tests.name: split-1.8
tests.script:
# Test: split on multiple characters
puts [split "a:b,c:d" :,]

tests.name: split-2.0
tests.script:
# Test: split with only separator characters
puts [llength [split ":::" :]]

tests.name: split-2.1
tests.script:
# Test: split single character string
puts [split "x" ""]

tests.name: split-2.2
tests.script:
# Test: split with no separator matches (returns single element list)
puts [split "hello" :]
puts [llength [split "hello" :]]

tests.name: split-2.3
tests.script:
# Test: split handles special list characters - creates valid list
set result [split "a{b}c" ""]
puts [llength $result]

tests.name: split-2.4
tests.script:
# Test: split with tab and newline in splitChars
puts [split "a\tb\nc" "\t\n"]

tests.name: split-3.0
tests.script:
# Test: split produces valid list from string with braces
set result [split "a}b{c" ""]
puts [lindex $result 0]
puts [lindex $result 1]
puts [lindex $result 2]

tests.name: split-3.1
tests.script:
# Test: split roundtrip with join
set original "a:b:c:d"
set parts [split $original :]
set rejoined [join $parts :]
puts $rejoined

tests.name: split-3.2
tests.script:
# Test: split preserves spaces in elements when not splitting on space
puts [split "a b:c d" :]

tests.name: split-3.3
tests.script:
# Test: split with dollar sign character
set result [split {a$b$c} {$}]
puts [llength $result]
puts [lindex $result 1]

tests.name: split-3.4
tests.script:
# Test: split string containing backslash
set result [split {a\b\c} "\\"]
puts [llength $result]
